ity Right to Know Act (EPCRA) by notifying the State Emergency Response Commission (SERC), the Local County Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and the local Fire Department of the presence of ammonia at the site.  Ryder Integrated Logistics Rochelle 1 files a Tier 2 Chemical Inventory each year with the Ogle County LEPC and the Fire Department as required by sections 311 and 312 of EPCRA.  The facility's Emergency Action Plan includes procedures for notifying the proper agencies in the event of a reportable release of ammonia.  A release of 100 pounds or more during a 24 hour period must be reported to the National Response Center, the SERC, and LEPC, in accordance with section 304 of EPCRA.  The Rochelle City Fire Department has been provided with a copy of the facility's Emergency Action Plan.

 
1.0	INTRODUCTION

This plan is prepared to document the preparation of a Risk Management Plan for the ammonia system operated by Ryder and owned by Ryder Integrated Logistics Rochelle 1 at their facility located 975 South Caron Rd. Rochelle, IL. 61068 The elements contained are to satisfy the requirements stated in 40 CFR 68 for a program 3 system.  


2.0	MANAGEMENT PLAN

The Facility Manager has overall responsibility for implementation of the Risk Management Plan.  He shall designate personnel, as he deems appropriate, to be responsible for specific elements of the plan.  Appendix A contains the identity of the Facility Manager and the individuals responsible for each element of the plan.  This list will be updated as necessary when personnel changes occur at the facility or the plan is updated.

3.0	OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

The offsite consequence analysis required by the Risk Management Program identifies the distance a released chemical travels until it reaches its toxic endpoint.  Toxic Endpoint is defined as the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without exp

eriencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action.  The Toxic Endpoint for anhydrous ammonia is listed in 40 CFR 68, Appendix A as 0.14 mg/l or 200 ppm.

3.1	Worst Case Scenario

The worst case scenario is based upon the maximum amount of ammonia to be collected into the largest single vessel in the system.  Overall Intended System Inventory capacity is approximately 30,000 lbs. of ammonia as noted in the PSI information of the PSM Program. The system has five storage vessels, (V-1) high temperature receiver vessel, (V-2) High temperature recirculator vessel and three low temperature recirculator vessels (V-3), (V-4), & (V-5), two thermosyphon vessels (V-6) & (V-7).  The largest single vessel in the facility's system is the Low Temperature recirculator vessel (V-4).  In the case of a system pumpdown, ammonia will be transferred to the low temperature recirculator vessels (V-3), (V-4), & (V-5). The capacity of the low temperature recirculator vessel (V-4) at 100% is approximately 12400 lbs as the Worst Case ammonia quantity.  The design of V-4 low temperature recirculator vessel system pumpdown capacity is approximately 80% of the vessel volume at HLCO vessel equaling approximately 7907.4 lbs.  The worst case scenario is based upon release of 100% volume from the V-4 low temperature recirculator vessel of 1240 lbs in ten minutes (release rate of 680 lbs/minute) due to a catastrophic vessel failure caused by overfilling/over pressurization.  The low temperature recirculator vessel (V-4) is located inside the engine room.  Distance to toxic endpoint is 1.2 miles.  This calculation was performed using the EPA's RMP*Comp Version 1.07 Program.  Vessel volume calculations, data, residential population estimates, receptors, and an RMP*Comp printout is included as Appendix B.  Residential population, receptors, and map information on this scenario was determined using MCDC

Missouri Census Data Center.


The capacity of the high temperature receiver vessel (V-1) at 100% is approximately 6781.7 lbs.  The nominal operating pressure of the V-1 system is 125-180 psig. The design V-1 high temperature receiver vessel pumpdown capacity is approximately 80% of the vessel volume at HLCO of approximately 4359.6 lbs.   


¿	The capacity of the high temperature recirculator vessel (V-2) at 100% is approximately 10,576.9 The nominal operating pressure of the V-2 system is 35-37psig.  
The design of V-2 high temperature recirculator vessel pump down capacity is approximately 80% of the vessel volume at HLCO of approximately 6799.3 lbs.   

¿	The capacity of the low temperature recirculator vessel (V-3) at 100% is approximately 10607 lbs.  The nominal operating pressure of the V-3 Vessel is 0-5# psig.
The design of V-3 Low temperature recirculator vessel pump down capacity is approximately 80% of the vessel volume at HLCO of approximately 6789.2 lbs. 

¿	The capacity of the low temperature recirculator vessel (V-5) at 100% is approximately 10367.1lbs.  The nominal operating pressure of the V-5 Vessel is 0-5# psig.
¿	The design of V-5 Low temperature recirculator vessel pump down capacity is approximately 80% of the vessel volume at HLCO of approximately 4562.1 lbs. 

¿	 The capacity of the Thermosyphon Receiver vessel (V-6) at 100% is approximately 1165.8.lbs.  The nominal operating pressure of the V-6 Vessel is 125 to 180 psig.
The design of V-6 Thermosyphon receiver vessel pump down capacity is approximately 80% of the vessel volume is approximately 525.8 lbs.  

¿	The capacity of the Thermosyphon Receiver vessel (V-7) at 100% is approximately 806.4.lbs.  The nominal operating pressure of the V-7 Vessel is 125 to 180 psig.
The design of V-7 Thermosyphon receiver vessel pump down capacity is approximately 80% of the vessel volume is approximately 518.4 lbs. 
 


3.2	Alternate Scenario

The federal rule requires that an alte

liance audits, and contractor qualifications.  The RMP/PSM program are reviewed annually and updated as necessary.  All significant changes to the system are reviewed in accordance with the PSM / RMP management of change provisions in the facility's plan.

The system is monitored and inspected by technicians that are trained, qualified, and experienced in ammonia refrigeration in accordance with the facility's PSM program.  The system is controlled automatically and monitored by the Global Refrigeration Computer Control System for proper operation 24 hours per day.  System parameters are logged in a permanent record, as are routine maintenance activities in a computer base maintenance management program (AMMS). Walking inspections are conducted on intervals not longer than 8 hours per day when staffed.

The system is equipped with a series of redundant failsafe devices, sensors, and overrides.  In the event a malfunction occurs that could result in an ammonia release, these protective devices shut the system down.  The system can't be restarted until the cause of the shutdown is identified and corrected.  The system is equipped with a shutdown system that is triggered by the presence of ammonia in the engine room.  The system shutdown can be manually operated using an emergency stop switch located outside the engine room, in the adjacent room and from a remote system computer.

The facility has made arrangements with the Rochelle Fire Department to respond to emergencies involving ammonia.  The facility conducts periodic incident evacuation drills.  The facility has never experienced an ammonia release that resulted in employee, contractor or off-site injuries, or offsite evacuation or sheltering in place.  Facility personnel are trained to safely control small, incidental releases of ammonia in the event they should occur.

 
Ryder Integrated Logistics Rochelle 1 has complied with the requirements of section 302 and 303 of the Emergency Planning and Commun

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Ryder operates the Ryder Integrated Logistics Rochelle 1, primary business is refrigerated warehousing with cooler, freezer product storage and distribution docks.  The facility is located at 975 South Caron Road, Rochelle, IL. 61068.The SIC code for the operation is 4222 the NAICS code is 49312.  The facility has approximately 110 full time employees and operates 24 hours/day, 6 days/week, 52 weeks/year.

The facility operates an ammonia refrigeration system as part of the process to keep food products fresh.  40 CFR 68.130 lists anhydrous ammonia as a hazardous chemical subject to RMP regulation with a threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds or greater.  

The current capacity of the system exceeds 10,000 pounds. The facility has never experienced a significant release incident.  Ammonia is recirculated in the system as a liquid and gas depending on system operating pressures and temperatures.  The refrigeration system is designed, installed and operated in accordance with the applicable guidelines and standards of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), the American National Standards Institute (ANSI), the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR), the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating, and Air-conditioning Engineers, Inc. (ASHRAE).  

The facility has developed and implemented a Process Safety Management Program (PSM) in accordance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.  Qualified outside contractors are used for construction and major repairs or modifications to the system.  The facility's PSM program includes provisions for process hazard analyses, management of change, pre-start up safety reviews, safe work practices, inspections, testing, maintenance, comp

rnative release scenario be selected that will reach an endpoint offsite unless no such scenario exists.  40 CFR 68.28 states that the facility should include, but not be limited to, consideration of the following:

¿	Transfer hose releases due to splits or sudden hose uncoupling.

The facility charging point is equipped with a check valve to prevent back flow of ammonia from the high pressure liquid system in the event of a charging hose failure.  The delivery trucks are equipped with excessive flow stop valves.  This scenario would result in a minimal release of ammonia.

¿	Process piping releases from failures at flanges, joints, welds, valves and valve seals, and drains or bleeds.






The facility selected three scenarios for this element:

3/4 outside HTRL pipe containing 21ºF @ 90 psig liquid ammonia from the V-2 high temperature recirculated liquid system outside the building with a release rate of 886.7 lbs/minute for 15 minute duration (due to the overall Intended System Inventory capacity of approximately 13,300 lbs. of ammonia as noted in the PSI information of the PSM Program, the total ammonia charge would be released within 15 minutes) distance to toxic endpoint is .2 mile; 

3/4 outside LTRL pipe containing -21ºF @ 65 psig liquid ammonia from the V-3 low temperature recirculated liquid system outside the building with a release rate of 762.5 lbs/minute for 17.1 minute duration (due to the overall Intended System Inventory capacity of approximately 13,300 lbs. of ammonia as noted in the PSI information of the PSM Program, the total ammonia charge would be released within 16.5 minutes) distance to toxic endpoint is 0.2 mile;

1/2 inside TSS pipe containing 95ºF @ 180 psig liquid ammonia from the V-1 thermosyphon vessel TSS high pressure liquid system to the compressor oil coolers, inside the building with a release rate of 545.28 lbs/minute for 2.6 minute duration (due to the overall Intended System Inventory capacity of approxim

gn, therefore no pump seal release scenarios were considered
The PRV release events are representative of potential scenarios identified by the PHA performed at the facility and typical facility experience (§68.28(e).

The scenario selected for the alternate release is a liquid release from small bore (3/4 pipe diameter) piping in the high pressure liquid pressure supply system located outside the building on the roof.  This is typical of the system small bore piping that is also present on system compressors, thermosyphon, recirculators, evaporators and other equipment.  Small bore pipe is located on the roof and inside the compressor room, it is not subject to traffic nor is it easily accessible as is the piping inside the engine room, but is considered to be the a more real life release scenario.  A release associated with a pump seal fail does not apply as the pumps are hermitic which do not have shaft seals, the release scenario from the V-4 operating liquid level catastrophic release was covered in the Worst Case and vessel pad sitting protection was considered, the release from a PRV valve toxic endpoint is minimal; therefore these scenarios were not selected. 

The alternate scenario release chosen was the outside HPL 3/4 PO valve, (due to the number of locations and possibilities throughout the system with a release rate calculated at approximately 1509.65 lb/min (at 90 psig) for a 8.9 minute duration (due to the overall Intended System Inventory capacity of approximately 30,000 lbs. of ammonia as noted in the PSI information of the PSM Program, the total ammonia charge would be released within 20 minutes).  The release rate is calculated using the equations published in the NH3 New May/June 1995 by W. V. Richards, P.E.  This is consistent with the EPA's recommendations for an alternate release scenario in the RMP guidance document.  Using EPA*Comp, Version 1.07, the amount released would be approximately 13,300 lbs.  The toxic endpoint is estimated

If the facility status changes such that the ammonia system is no longer subject to the requirements of 
40 CFR 68, an amended registration shall be submitted to the EPA within six months indicating that the facility is no longer covered.

All records required to document the implementation of this program will be retained for a period not less than five (5) years.

A copy of the toxic endpoint worksheet for the alternate release scenario, residential population, and receptors (Landview 6), and the release rate calculation worksheets are included in Appendix C.
 

4.0	FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There are no known accidents or releases associated with the ammonia refrigeration system within the past five years which resulted in deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, or evacuations, either onsite or off-site.

5.0	PREVENTION PROGRAM

The facility has implemented under separate cover a Process Safety Management Program which meets the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119.  That program is incorporated into this program by reference and satisfies the requirements of the prevention program of 40 CFR 68 Subpart D.

6.0	EMERGENCY RESPONSE

The facility has implemented an Emergency Action and Spill Prevention, Contingency and Countermeasure  Plan which meets the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.38, and the requirements of 
40 CFR 68.95.  The Emergency Response Plan is incorporated into this plan by reference.

Copies of the Emergency Action Plan are available to the Local Fire Department and the Ogle/Lee County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  The contents of the plan have been discussed with these agencies.  Plan updates and changes will be communicated with these agencies as they occur.

 

7.0	REGISTRATION AND CERTIFICATION

A copy of the registration information and required certification submitted for this facility's ammonia refrigeration system is included as Appendix E.

8.0	UPDATES AND RECORDKEEPING

This plan shall be updated as follows:

No later than the date:	¿	A regulated chemical is first present above a threshold quantity in a new process
¿	A new regulated chemical is first present in an already covered process above a threshold quantity
Within one month of:	¿	A change to the emergency contact person information
